title: 115_hr5270
content: The Act is titled the "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" and includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under section 45T of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units, where taxpayers can claim a credit equal to 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating, whichever is lower. Qualified expenses refer to costs related to the operation of the unit that uses coal for at least 75% of electricity production. The term 'coal-powered electric generation unit' refers to a unit using coal for at least 75% of electricity production. 'Qualified expenses' are costs for operating or maintaining the unit, excluding coal costs. Public entities can transfer the tax credit to another entity if eligible. For any taxable year, if a qualified public entity elects, the eligible project partner will be treated as the taxpayer for the specified credit. A qualified public entity is defined as a government entity at the federal, state, or local level. The subsection defines a qualified public entity as a government entity at the federal, state, or local level, a mutual or cooperative electric company, or a not-for-profit electric utility that received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. The term 'eligible project partner' for a coal-powered electric generation unit includes those responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing the unit, participating in coal provision, providing financing, or leasing the unit. The tax credit applies to partnerships where a qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer for their share of the credit. Any partner of the partnership is considered an eligible project partner. The tax credit applies to partnerships with a qualified public entity as the taxpayer for their share of the credit, including any partner of the partnership. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit derived by an eligible project partner is subject to private use rules. The tax credit applies to partnerships with a qualified public entity as the taxpayer for their share of the credit. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner after the qualified public entity's taxable year. Any benefit derived by an eligible project partner in connection with the credit election is not considered private business use. The basis of a coal-powered electric generation unit is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years between December 31, 2017, and January 1, 2023. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units reduces the basis of the property by the amount of the credit allowed. This section applies to taxable years between December 31, 2017, and January 1, 2023. Additionally, there are amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code to allow the credit against alternative minimum tax. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units is amended to include a new clause for the credit determined under section 45T. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The tax credit for coal-powered electric generation units is amended to include a new clause for the credit determined under section 45T.
